NATHANIEL ACORN

PRINCE ALBERT.

PUBLIC NOTICE.

Public Notice is hereby given that the Secretary of the North West Territories has appointed Mr. Nathan Acorn as Assessor for the School Board.

The new policy act is to be enforced.

The Territorial system of land tenure will be introduced in the North West.

Liberal grants of land are to be given to those who build houses in the North West.

May I mention, Mr. McNaughton, is to be elected President of Manitoba.

The evidence is strong against the North West Territories.

The Crown Government is to change the charge to high taxation.

The Canadian government are at Canada very way loose.

Their services are being further required.

Gen. Stewart is recovering from his wound.

Gen. Earl has had some heavy fighting on the Iron Ore coast, but was very successful.

The French have been victorious in a late engagement in China, carrying away a large number of prisoners.

A new political alliance between France and United States is anticipated.

CURLANDIA.

On Tuesday last a match was played between Curlandia and Prince Albert, the result of the day's play being a victory for the Curlandia team by eight shots.

THE SCHOOL BOARD.

The first meeting of the Prince Albert Public School Board took place on Monday, February 2nd, all the members being present.

The first business done was to elect a secretary for the Board.

It was moved by Mr. Macdonald, seconded by Mr. Macdonald, that the Board be instructed to advertise in the newspapers for a secretary.

Moved by Mr. Macdonald, seconded by Mr. Macdonald, that the Board be instructed to advertise in the newspapers for a teacher.

Considerable discussion ensued as to the advisability of engaging a secretary to conduct the school. Mr. Macdonald stated that he had heard that much work should be done by members of the Board. This was answered, however, that the secretary instructed to advertise.

The secretary was instructed to apply for a teacher, and a half dozen copies of the North West ordinances.

The Board will place themselves in communication with the trustees of the Methodist Church in order to secure the use of their building as a schoolhouse.

The Board then adjourned till Feb. 15th.

FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1885.

HUDSON'S BAY ROUTE.

It is much to be regretted that the press and people of the North-West are not more attentive to the subject of the Hudson's Bay route, which is more prominently to the front than they appear to do. It may certainly seem to us in the Territories that it is a matter of some importance at this juncture, and in the interests of its inhabitants Manitoba cannot secure what is so much to be desired with regard to this, it is useless for us to interfere, and that we had better devote ourselves to getting such returns as may accrue to us more immediately within our reach. It should none the less be remembered that the mightiest rivers are formed and fed by little rills, and however remote the advantages possessed by each may seem to him or herself should be used. A large proportion of the inhabitants of these Territories consists of people who have been and still are engaged in eastern provinces, with whom they correspond, and who must take a lively interest in their welfare, and there can be no doubt but that the opportunity offered by the advantages of the Hudson's Bay route among the people of the eastern provinces generally might be materially enhanced by a judicious use of private correspondence. That there exists a strong necessity for the establishment of public opinion in this end in this regard is unfortunately only too evident, although it is not so easy to see how this end may be accomplished.

In the present state of matters, it behooves the whole Dominion to secure the prosperity of the Territories, for undoubtedly the people in the eastern provinces have got the idea very firmly fixed in their minds that so long as the Hudson's Bay route remains open, the advantage of the route will be enjoyed by the eastern provinces, and that the people of the Territories will be left behind.

Toronto merchants say the published crop reports of the North-West are either misleading or their customers in that section are not truthful, if the harvest was so good then there would be reason why money should not be more plentiful and old accounts wiped out. It might surely occur to them that an abundant harvest does not necessarily mean an over-supply of cash. It is said that the farmers are in want of proper facilities for sending it to market—the profits go in cost of transportation—therefore it is not fair to blame the farmers for not making the most of their crops. The Hudson Bay route opened and they will soon handle a good deal more of our cash.

THE DYNAMITERS.

London, Jan. 26.—The excitement over the dynamite outrage has remained unabated today, and every move and development is eagerly watched by the public. The authorities are vigilantly guarding against the possibility of further attacks, as well as striving to find out the author of Saturday's work. The letters recently received, disclosing the dynamiters' plans, tended to incite them to greater efforts.

Westminster Hall and the Tower were closed today to everyone except those officially interested in inspecting the buildings. The approaches to all public buildings are rigidly guarded, and nobody is allowed to enter without submitting to the closest scrutiny. The Tower and Parliament houses were surrounded by sentries. Immense crowds of people visit the vicinity of the ruins daily. Visitors are forbidden admission to Windsor Castle.

THE DYNAMITER SUSPECT.

Interest was greatly centred today in the prisoner Cunningham, who was arrested at the Tower on the day of the explosion. The prisoner was conveyed to Bow Street Station by a strong guard of police, suspected of complicity in the explosion at the Tower of London. He is 16 years of age, of medium height, dark hair and eyes, short stature, and sinister expression. He willingly answered the questions put to him, which he answered within sight to a glimpse of the alleged dynamiter. The prisoner gave his full name as James Gilbert Cunningham, and asserted that he was an Englishman.

Inspector Hubberley deposed that he examined the prisoner at the tower; that he (the prisoner) was confined and gave contradictory answers to his questions. The prisoner, the inspector said, had given a wrong address as the place of his abode, and then stated he lived in Scarborough street, Whitechapel, worked on the docks at Liverpool until the beginning of last year, when he came to London to try to better himself. He formerly resided in America. The inspector further stated that the prisoner was known at his lodgings as Dalton. His luggage had been searched, but the contents had not been made known to the public.

The examination of Cunningham tended to convince the police that they had secured a person who had a guilty knowledge of Saturday's crime. It was stated that Cunningham was a native of Cork, that he lived for five years in the United States, arriving in England during last autumn. He was described as an Irishman who was well carried out, until the close examination in court, when he forgot himself and threw off his slow, stammering manner. Cunningham is the only suspect now in jail.

THE INFERNAL MACHINES.

It is known that the infernal machines used to cause the disaster were fired by sulphuric acid, which worked through the fuse and exploded the cap beneath. The police occupy twenty minutes time to allow the conspirators to escape before the explosion took place.

CUNNINGHAM'S REVELATIONS.

It is reported that Cunningham has made important revelations, in consequence of which all trains leaving London for the western towns are accompanied by detectives.

DAVITT'S OPINIONS.

Michael Davitt interviewed today about the London outrage, said the dynamite operations had spread throughout Ireland, and fewer in America than was generally supposed. He said he believed the recent outrages in Ross were not actuated by nationalistic or blood-thirsty motives. He said he thought the dynamiters would be more dangerous in the near future. In conclusion, he said the best way to combat the dynamiters was by showing them that the manipulating of Irish grievances in Britain would be futile. He said that the Irish should continue to use King's only expression of goodwill to wards Ireland.

CANADIAN.

Ottawa, Jan. 26.—Mr. Davies, Post Office Inspector, who was in Chicago in connection with the arrest of A. R. Campbell, the Canadian man robber, has left that city. He has not given any such information from Stewart as may yet implicate others in respect to the crime.

Lt. Colonel Trutch, the Dominion Government agent for British Columbia, arrived here yesterday afternoon.

The liquor men of Stewart, Dundas and Glengarry will enter a new action to test, in the Supreme Court, the capital punishment law.

Montreal, Jan. 26.—A suspicious looking box was found in the post office building but was opened by the police. It was at once removed to the police station. The box weighed three pounds, and contained a quantity of dynamite. Experts have been called for examination.

Special prayers were offered yesterday in several of the city churches for the safety of the British soldiers in the South.

The Boulevard to St. Hubert's Island and the Condominiums, the latter covered entirely with sugar maple, is now finished. Several leading members of the Ice Carnival Committee drove across the Boulevard yesterday afternoon.

The majority of those enjoying the drive were American visitors.

A very interesting and valuable arrangement has been arrived at between the North Shore and Canadian Pacific railroads.

Dr. Enock, a physician of high standing, will appear Monday for the benefit of the sick.

Toronto, Jan. 26.—The graduates of Trinity University met tonight to decide upon the proper course of action to take.

The house of Mr. Smith was in the most excellent, but it was decided to engage the services of Mr. Smith.

The right of way has been taken and has been placed upon the endowment fund.

MISS MACKAY CO.,

ESTRAY HORSE.

Under and by virtue of ordinance No. 9 of 1883 of the North-West Territories, it is notified that a Rockingham pony, the property of Mr. Smith, has been stolen. The horse is described as being 14 hands shoulder, black mane and tail, in an excellent condition.

The right of way has been taken and has been placed upon the endowment fund.
